instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4.99v @.080A
threads.message:
Hi, I am checking this board, it was a bit dusty, it stopped working suddenly, no water damage or so. Found that a trace was missing from <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> (2) to <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> (4) so I put a jumper in it, did that, but still not turning on, when I turn it on with my PSU sometimes I get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 12.6v  @.020A and sometimes I get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 4.99V @.080A. Have replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, same behavior.
There is a weird thing, on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> pin 6, I get .850v and I think I am supposed to get 3.3v there am I right? Anyway, when the board is at .080A there is no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. but when it is at .020A I do get the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> line.
<CHIP>U7941</CHIP>
PIN 1-3 = 3.3V
PIN 4 = 0V
PIN 5 = 0V
PIN 6 = 3.3V
PIN 7 = 0V
PIN 8 = 3.3V

ANOTHER WEIRD THING, WHEN I TURN OFF MY PSU IF I MEASURE PIN 2 OF F7040 VOLTAGE IS NOT 0V IT IS AROUND 3V AND DROPPING...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 4.99v @.080A
threads.message:
Allow 10-15s to discharge remanent voltages, once power is removed.

Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages (when problem appears); pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Also post the exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28.
